I didn't expect so much backlash to this question. I just wanted to know if Jazz fans thought the name was strange because of its origins.
Obviously all the names are "strange" in one sense or another, but the only other team that was named after a local characteristic and then moved but kept the name is the Lakers. From my experience those fans don't consider it a weird situation and I was wondering how that compared to Jazz fans.
Everyone knows jazz is illegal in Utah.
Am I the only one who realizes these are two different situations?
This is the real tragedy. New Orleans deserves that name.

I mean Jazz was born in New Orleans. Honestly I think The Utah Jazz makes less sense than the Toronto Raptors because dinosaurs are a part of western pop culture, including Toronto. Jazz has no connection to Utah (obviously).

Black Mirror is an anthology show. Every episode is very different from one another. Almost every episode is directed by a different person and is working on different themes.
It should not be a surprise that the reaction to episodes are so polarizing.

All three wrestle with the American dream and the human condition in profound ways. The Great American novel on the small screen.
When I think of A+ television I only think of these three. There is a lot of A, A-, B+ TV out there but in my mind these are the only three that deserve a perfect grade.
Mad Men went off the air almost two years ago. It has been two years since A+ TV. I miss it. But I am confident we will get a successor.
The Twilight Zone is my favorite short story.

Coates is infinitely more intelligent than I am so I cannot speak for him.
Foote was a product of the early 20th century American South - a place where the government had been defined by white supremacy for decades. To deny that is to deny history.
Frankly, if you're not operating in bad faith this stuff really isn't that difficult to grasp.

I think you may have gotten to the core of the negative reaction to Coates' argument.
You write that Coates is attacking whiteness, when in fact he is simply presenting a historical analysis. I assume you are white and see that as an attack on yourself, which in turn evokes an emotional reaction.
Dr. Robin DiAngelo would [define this as white fragility.](http://libjournal.uncg.edu/ijcp/article/viewFile/249/116)
White Fragility is a state in which even a minimum amount of racial stress becomes intolerable, triggering a range of defensive moves. These moves include the outward display of emotions such as anger, fear, and guilt, and behaviors such as argumentation, silence, and leaving the stress-inducing situation.
I encourage you to read her paper.
Could you elaborate? It is impossible to find literary criticism from an author who has no particular viewpoint.

If someone wants to argue that Foote is overly sympathetic to the Confederate cause they should critique Footes actual words, like you did by posting that paragraph from him, not by claiming that his "whiteness" prevented him from reaching the right conclusions.
I pulled the Foote quote directly from Coates' article. If you followed the link you could clearly see Coates addresses Foote's actual words. I really didn't add much to the argument, it all comes from Coates. I explicitly wrote that you need to read the entire thing to get context.
Ta-Nehisi Coates article is racist, plain and simple. I happen to agree that Foote was a bit to sympathatic to the "Cause," but that is due to my analysis of his arguments, which I can attribute to his attitudes, upbringing, and values, not the color of his skin.
To declare Coates' analysis of Foote as racist is baffling, again please read the entire article. In analyzing Foote's view of the Civil War you can not separate his upbringing and values with his race - they are, in essence, one and the same.

Ta-Nehisi Coates' Atlantic piece [The Convenient Suspension of Disbelief](https://www.theatlantic.com/national/archive/2011/06/the-convenient-suspension-of-disbelief/240318/) argues that ultimately Foote was sympathetic to confederate figures and not to slaves, simply because he could see himself as a confederate and not as a slave.
He gave twenty years of his life, and three volumes of important and significant words to the Civil War, but he he could never see himself in the slave. He could not get that the promise of free bread can not cope with the promise of free hands. Shelby Foote wrote The Civil War, but he never understood it. Understanding the Civil War was a luxury his whiteness could ill-afford.
I pulled this passage from an interview that accompanies the story, it is important to read the entire thing to get context.
INTERVIEWER:
Had you been alive during the Civil War, would you have fought for the Confederates?
FOOTE:
No doubt about it. What's more, I would fight for the Confederacy today if the circumstances were similar. There's a great deal of misunderstanding about the Confederacy, the Confederate flag, slavery, the whole thing. The political correctness of today is no way to look at the middle of the nineteenth century. The Confederates fought for some substantially good things. States rights is not just a theoretical excuse for oppressing people. You have to understand that the raggedy Confederate soldier who owned no slaves and probably couldn't even read the Constitution, let alone understand it, when he was captured by Union soldiers and asked, What are you fighting for? replied, I'm fighting because you're down here. So I certainly would have fought to keep people from invading my native state. There's another good reason for fighting for the Confederacy. Life would have been intolerable if you hadn't. The women of the South just would not allow somebody to stay home and sulk while the war was going on. It didn't take conscription to grab him. The women made him go.
Foote is an excellent story teller but it is difficult to agree that he did not contribute to a body of text from which, in part, white nationalism claims.
P.S.: If this discussion interests you check out [Vox's piece of the famous Ballou letter.](http://www.vox.com/culture/2017/1/21/14338656/chuck-schumer-inauguration-speech-sullivan-ballou)
lol did you just unironically link to Zero Hedge?
